expanded_description: Understanding the difference between relations and functions is fundamental to algebra. A relation is any set of ordered pairs, while a function is a special type of relation where each input has exactly one output. This distinction forms the basis for function notation, domain and range, and all subsequent work with functions.

core_concept.principle: A relation is a set of ordered pairs. A function is a relation in which each input (x-value) has exactly one output (y-value). In other words, no two ordered pairs in a function can have the same first element with different second elements. The set of all inputs is the domain; the set of all outputs is the range.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a function as a vending machine. You press a button (input) and get exactly one snack (output). If pressing the same button could give you different snacks at different times, that would be confusing—that's not how vending machines work. A relation is like a list of who likes what snack—one person might like multiple snacks, and multiple people might like the same snack, but in a function, each input has exactly one output.

image.caption: Figure 3.2.1: A function is like a vending machine—each input has exactly one output.

key_concept.definition: A relation is any set of ordered pairs (x, y). The set of all first elements (x-values) is the domain, and the set of all second elements (y-values) is the range. Relations can be represented in multiple ways: as a set of ordered pairs, as a table, as a graph, as a mapping diagram, or as an equation.
key_concept.context: Relations appear everywhere—in data sets, in equations, in real-world relationships like temperature over time. Understanding how to represent and interpret relations in multiple formats is essential for working with functions.

sections.introduction: A function is a special type of relation with a specific rule: each input must have exactly one output.

introduction_image.alt: Function machine: input goes in, exactly one output comes out
introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.2.13: A function takes each input to exactly one output.

key_concept.definition: A function is a relation in which each element of the domain (input) is paired with exactly one element of the range (output). In other words, no two ordered pairs in a function can have the same first element with different second elements. Functions can be represented the same ways as relations, but they must satisfy this condition.
key_concept.context: Functions are the building blocks of mathematics. They model relationships where one quantity depends on another in a predictable way: distance depends on time, cost depends on quantity, temperature depends on location. Understanding functions allows us to describe, predict, and analyze these relationships.

image.alt: Side-by-side comparison: a function (each x→one y) and a non-function (one x→two y's)
image.caption: Figure 3.2.14: Functions vs. non-functions.

classifications.value: A function where each input has a unique output AND each output has a unique input.
characteristics: Each x maps to exactly one y
Each y is mapped from exactly one x
Passes both vertical and horizontal line tests
classifications.behavior: The most restrictive type of function—each pairing is unique in both directions.

image.alt: Mapping diagram showing one-to-one correspondence
image.caption: Figure 3.2.15: One-to-one function.

examples.explanation: Each x different, each y different—one-to-one

classifications.value: A function where multiple inputs can share the same output.
characteristics: Each x maps to exactly one y
Different x's can map to same y
Passes vertical line test, fails horizontal line test
classifications.behavior: Still a function—the definition only restricts inputs, not outputs.

image.alt: Mapping diagram showing multiple arrows pointing to same y-value
image.caption: Figure 3.2.16: Many-to-one function.

examples.explanation: All inputs map to same output 3—still a function

classifications.value: A relation where a single input has multiple outputs.
characteristics: At least one x-value appears with different y-values
Fails the vertical line test
Not a function by definition
classifications.behavior: Violates the definition of a function—cannot be a function.

image.alt: Mapping diagram showing one x with arrows to multiple y's
image.caption: Figure 3.2.17: One-to-many relation—NOT a function.

examples.explanation: x=1 appears with y=2 and y=3—not a function

principles.statement: A graph represents a function if and only if no vertical line intersects the graph at more than one point.
principles.application: To test if a graph is a function, imagine drawing vertical lines across the entire graph. If any vertical line touches the graph in more than one place, the graph is not a function.

image.alt: Two graphs: left passes vertical line test (function), right fails (not a function)
image.caption: Figure 3.2.18: The vertical line test.

principles.statement: A function is one-to-one if and only if no horizontal line intersects the graph at more than one point.
principles.application: After confirming a graph is a function, use the horizontal line test to determine if it's one-to-one. This is important for inverse functions.

image.alt: Two functions: left fails horizontal line test (many-to-one), right passes (one-to-one)
image.caption: Figure 3.2.19: The horizontal line test for one-to-one functions.

sections.section_title: 3.2.3 Domain and Range of Relations and Functions
sections.introduction: Every relation has a domain (set of inputs) and a range (set of outputs). Understanding how to find domain and range from different representations is essential.

key_concept.definition: The domain of a relation is the set of all first elements (x-values). The range is the set of all second elements (y-values). For functions, these sets have special importance because each domain element must map to exactly one range element.
key_concept.context: Domain and range tell us what values are possible inputs and outputs. In real-world applications, domain and range are often restricted by practical considerations (you can't have negative time, for example).

worked_examples.title: Real-World Function Identification

image.alt: Real-world scenarios to analyze
image.caption: Figure 3.2.45: Determine if each scenario represents a function.

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each situation represents a function. Explain your reasoning.
a) The height of a growing plant measured each day
b) A person's age and their weight
c) The number of students in a class and the number of desks in the room

step_by_step.explanation: At each day (input), there is exactly one height measurement (output). This is a function.

A given age could correspond to many different weights (different people). Also, a given weight could correspond to many ages. The relationship is not a function in either direction unless we specify which is input and which is output.
For a given number of students, there could be different numbers of desks (rooms can have extra desks). For a given number of desks, there could be different numbers of students. Not a function.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Function, b) Not necessarily a function, c) Not a function
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world relationships are functions only when each input has exactly one output.

summary: A relation is any set of ordered pairs (x, y). Relations can be represented as sets, tables, graphs, or mapping diagrams. A function is a special type of relation where each input (x-value) has exactly one output (y-value). This means no two ordered pairs in a function can have the same first element with different second elements. The vertical line test provides a quick visual way to determine if a graph represents a function: if any vertical line intersects the graph at more than one point, the graph is not a function. Functions can be one-to-one (each input has unique output and each output has unique input) or many-to-one (multiple inputs can share the same output). The domain of a function is the set of all possible inputs; the range is the set of all possible outputs. Real-world examples of functions include temperature as a function of time, cost as a function of quantity, and area as a function of radius. Understanding the distinction between relations and functions is fundamental to all advanced work in algebra, calculus, and mathematical modeling.
